moves.1. d4 Nf6: This game comes from King Inidan Defense mini-tournament
moves.2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 Bg7: King's Indian. I am more a Pirc player than King's Indian
moves.5... O-O 6. Be3 c5: The c5 break! It is a gambit, if you will. I play 6...c5 against the Saemisch 100% of the time.
moves.7. Nge2 Qa5: I am unsure what better move there is. (the point of these public annotated games) White did not push his pawn to d5.
moves.12. Qxd3 Nd7:
?? this was a bad move on my part. Better would be 12...b5 with another gambit 
(cxb...axb; Nxb...Ba6) Then I would attack on a & b files withe my two rooks, then play Nd7 opening up the long diagonal for my dark square bishop. Attacking in the Benko gambit fashion
moves.14. bxc3 b5 15. O-O bxc4 16. Qxc4 Nb6 17: ?? Now I am stuck with a inactive bishop for most of the game. I got the Bb7 idea from playing too many Pirc games. That unblock c pawn really makes a difference.
moves.25. e5: !? uh oh! Now I am starting to feel the shadow of defeat
I here my bishop becomes active! Taking step #1 
The start of his Zig Zag journey
moves.33. Qf3 Qd7: I was prepared to exchange pieces now. I believe my opponent did not see the reason behind Qd7 back up by the bishop. The Zig Zag motion by my bishop saved me from defeat. Yes white can capture the h pawn but it is bait! Once we exchange pieces we'll have opposite color bishop's
moves.34. Nxf6 Rxf6: !! This is one of the reason why I play Kxf7 earlier, as to let my rook maneuver about here and fro
moves.37. Qxf5 Bxf5: At last my bishop is free! Now we have a theoretical draw. Bishops of opposite color tend to be drawish. I offer my opponent a draw but he decline. (sigh)
moves.38. Ke2: If anybody can calculate a win for either side please, leave a comment.
moves.42. Kb2 Bd3 43. Kc3: The king is toiling and struggling
moves.45. h4 a3: I do not know if I should have played a3 or something else

gameName: King's Indian B v B & pawns endgame
